title-group.article-title: Effects of various pine needle extracts on Chinese hamster ovary cell growth and monoclonal antibody quality

abstract.p: Abstract Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells are commonly used as “bio-machines” to pro-duce monoclonal antibodies (mAb) because of their ability to produce very complex proteins. In this study, we evaluated the effects of pine needle water extract (PNWE), pine needle ethanol extract (PNEE), and pine needle polysaccharide extract (PNPE) on the CHO cell growth, mAb production and quality using a Fed-batch culture process. PNPE maintained high VCD and viability, and the titer increase was correlated with its concentration. Three extracts effectively reduced the acidic charge variant and modulated mAb glycosylation. PNPE had the most profound effect, with G0F decreasing by 8.7% and G1Fa increasing by 6.7%. The change in the glycoform was also closely related to the PNPE concentration. This study demonstrated that PNPE could facilitate CHO cell growth, increase the mAb production, decrease acidic charge variants, and regulate mAb glycoforms. To identify the components responsible for the above changes, the sugar and flavonoid contents in the extracts were determined, and the chemical compounds were identified by LC-MS, resulting in 38 compounds identified from PNPE. Rich in sugars and flavonoids in these three extracts may be related to increased CHO cell growth and productivity, and changes in glycoforms.

sec.p: Introduction With the successful uses of mAb therapeutics to treat human diseases, the identification of suitable supplements for the development of new CHO cell culture media to increase mAb yields have become extremely important.[ 1 ] From the traditional animal serum medium to the chemically defined (CD) medium used today, medium components and their concentrations for increasing the yield of different types of mAbs have been greatly improved. Since the CD medium does not need to add substances, such as fetal bovine serum (FBS), the variation between media batches decreases greatly. As a result, the repeatability of the CHO cell culture increases, and the process becomes more stable and robust.[ 2 ] Recombinant proteins with specific characteristics can be obtained by developing a CHO cell line with a unique gene expression. However, the culture medium components and supplements can impact post-translational modifications of mAb.[ 3 ] In fact, the optimization of medium and supplement composition will affect the cell growth and the quality of protein produced by CHO cells.[ 4–6 ] Supplements are designed to replenish nutrients depleted in the basal medium, relieve cell stress, support cell growth, and ensure better mAb production. These supplements are usually added to media at the different stages during the cell culture processes, such as fed-batch culture.[ 7 , 8 ] Due to the high specificity of nutrients required for cell growth and product quality, it is necessary to evaluate the unique benefits of supplements in combination with culture media.[ 9 ] The results of these studies should provide critical information for designing new CD media and CD supplements to maximize the cell growth, increase the mAb titer, and control the product quality.[ 10 ] Many studies have found that pine needles are extremely rich in flavonoids, vitamins, amino acids, mineral elements, alkaloids, and polysaccharides.[ 11 ] And possess hypoglycemic, lipid regulation, antitumor, anti-aging, and antibacterial properties.[ 12 , 13 ] The natural water-soluble bioflavonoid concentrates and alkaloids from pine needle extracts have antioxidant activity functions, which can effectively remove free radicals.[ 14–16 ] Plant polysaccharides have a wide range of biological activities and desirable functional properties.[ 17 ] It has been reported that some small antioxidant molecules without direct nutritional value added to the cell culture medium can increase the productivity of CHO cells or protect the mAb from being oxidized.[ 18 ] Many infrequently used sugars, and the corresponding cellular response toward them as substrates led to differences in the protein N-glycosylation profile of a recombinant glycoprotein.[ 19 ] It has also been reported that the addition of bioflavonoids to animal cell cultures can effectively reduce the acidic charge variants on recombinant mAbs and their dual variable regions. Besides reducing the acidic charge variants of mAbs, the use of bioflavonoids can improve the structure and function of antibodies to varying degrees,[ 20 ] as well as product quality with less heterogeneity. The antioxidants, bioflavonoids, and polysaccharides in the pine needle extract have potential effects on the growth of CHO cells and the production of mAbs. In this study, three types of Masson pine needle extracts, water extract (PNWE), ethanol extract (PNEE), and polysaccharide extract (PNPE), were used to evaluate their effects on CHO cell growth, cell metabolism, and titer, charge variant, glycosylation and biological activity of mAb in a fed-batch process. The contents of carbohydrates, flavonoids, and chemical compounds in the pine needle extracts were determined to identify the possible relationship with the components present in these extracts. To our knowledge, there is not a precedent report for the use of pine needle extracts as supplements for CHO cell culture media.

Materials and methods Chemicals, reagents, and pine needle extracts Dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) and dextrose dry powder were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (USA). Formic acid, methanol, acetonitrile, water, and trifluoroacetic acid (TFA) were ordered from Thermo Fisher Scientific (USA). Phenol concentrated sulfuric acid, sodium chloride, sodium hydroxide, phosphate-buffered saline (PBS), and aluminum chloride were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., China. Rutin standard was ordered from Chengdu Nakeli Bio-Technology Corp. China. Chemically defined medium CHO 050, and supplement CD Feed were provided by Jianshun Biotechnology Co., Ltd., China, and the cell line used was a stable recombinant CHO K1 cell line provided by Thousand Oaks Biopharmaceuticals Corp., China. PNWE and PNEE were purchased from Shaanxi Sinuote Biotechnology Co., Ltd., China. PNPE was obtained from Lanzhou Wotelaisi Biotechnology Corp., China. PNWE and PNEE were extracted from the pine needle by water and 75% ethanol, respectively. PNPE were obtained from the pine needle by multi-step extraction with water. In PNPE 50% of the active ingredients are the polysaccharides according to the specification. Determinations of carbohydrate and flavonoid contents The carbohydrate content in the pine needle extracts was determined through the method of phenol-sulfuric acid using glucose as the standard. A stock solution with a glucose concentration of 0.1 mg/mL was prepared in water. A set of the standard solutions ranging from 0.02 to 1.0 mg/mL glucose were made for the standard curve. The sample (1 mg) was added to 10 mL of purified water and sonicated for 30 min. The supernatant was analyzed for the carbohydrate content. After adding 0.5 mL of 6% phenol and 2.5 mL of concentrated sulfuric acid solution to 1 mL of the standard and sample solutions, respectively, they were mixed and cooled at room temperature for 30 min, and absorbance at 490 nm was measured with an Evolution 260 Bio UV-Vis spectrophotometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA). The carbohydrate content in the sample was determined from the standard curve. The flavonoid content in the pine needle extracts was determined by using an aluminum chloride colorimetric method. Rutin dissolved in 50% methanol was used as the flavonoid standard and the standard calibration curve was prepared in the concentrations ranging from 10 and 80 µg/mL. For the extraction of flavornoids, 200 mg of the sample was added in 20 mL of 50% methanol, and sonicated for 30 min. The sample extract (2 mL) was then mixed with 1 mL of 1% aluminum chloride and 7 mL of 50% methanol. The mixtures were allowed to stand for 30 min at the room temperature and the absorbance was measured at 277 nm spectrophotometrically. The flavonoid content in the sample was determined from the standard curve. Identification of chemical compounds Each of the pine needle extracts (1 g) was accurately weighed into a 50 mL centrifugal tube and 20 mL of 75% methanol solution was added. Sonicated for 30 min, and the solution was filtrated. A 10.0-mL of the filtrate was dried under a reduced pressure. The dried sample was re-dissolved in 5 mL 75% methanol and then filtered with a 0.22 µm Polyether sulfone (PES) membrane. The filtrate was used for the identification of the chemical compounds. Identification was performed using a Zeno TOF 7600 mass spectrometer (SCIEX, USA) equipped with a Sepax GP-C18 analytical column (1.8 µm 2.1 × 150 mm, Sepax Technologies, Inc., China) and an ACQUITY UPLC system (Waters, USA). Mobile phase A was 0.1% formic acid in water and Mobile phase B was 0.1% formic acid in acetonitrile. The mobile gradient was 5% B at the first 3 min, 5–75%B from 3 to 10 min, 75–100% B from 10 to 10.5 min, 100% B from 10.5 to 16.5 min, and 100–5% B from 16.5 to 20 min. The column temperature was 35 °C and the flow rate was 0. 3 mL/min. The ESI ion source was used for the analysis. The ESI ion source settings were as follows: ion source gases 1 and 2 at 60 psi, curtain gas at 35 psi, CAD gas at 9 psi, temperature at 600 °C. TOF start-stop mass between 30 and 1000 Da, declustering potential at −80 V, collision energy at −10 V. MS/MS conditions were as follows: TOF start-stop mass between 20 and 1000 Da, collision energy at −35 V, CE spread at 15 V, accumulation time at 0.15 s, and an injection volume at 3 µL. The compound identification was carried out through the Sciex database and the compound was confirmed with both TIC and MS/MS spectrum matching scores of >70%. Cell fed-batch culture The stock solutions of the pine needle extracts were prepared in water at a concentration of 10 mg/mL. The stock solutions were sonicated for 30 min to allow the extracts to be dissolved completely and then filtered by 0.22 µm PES membrane before use. The cell line was serially propagated through separate seed train inoculums to generate enough cells for inoculation. Based on the preliminary experimental results, it was decided to use three concentrations of 5, 10, and 15 mg/L as the experimental concentration of the subsequent fed-batch culture for PNWE and PNEE. PNPE has a large concentration span, considering that the polysaccharide components have different effects on the charge variants and glycosylation of subsequent mAbs, three concentrations of 5, 50, and 100 mg/L were determined as the experimental concentrations of fed-batch culture. Nine experimental treatments with one control were used and each treatment including the control replicated three times. Independent cultures were performed in 50-mL cell culture TPP tubes (Switzerland). The working volume in each tube was 25 mL, and the seeding density was 1.0 × 106 viable cells/mL. The extracts were added to the cell culture media on Day 0 and the cells were harvested on Day 14. VCD and cell viability were determined with Vi-cell XR (Beckman Coulter, USA). Glucose, glutamine, lactate, ammonium, glutamate, pH, and osmolarity were determined with a BioProfile 400 (Nova BioMedical, USA). All samples were taken daily and assayed before feeding. The cells were fed with the CD feed on the 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, and 13 days, respectively. The two types of CD feeds were added at 4 and 0.4% of the feeding-day culture volume, respectively. Glucose was always kept at a concentration between 2 and 3 g/L based on the results tested daily. When the VCD exceeded 1.0 × 106 viable cells/mL, the cell density of the sample was diluted in a 1:1 ratio with PBS before measurement. A temperature was shifted from 37 to 32 °C on the 7th day of the culture. After the 14th day, the samples were centrifuged with a high-speed refrigerated centrifuge (Beckman Coulter, USA) at 20 °C, 3900 g for 30 min, and the supernatants were collected, respectively. The mAb titer assay An e2695 HPLC system (Waters, USA) with a TSKgel Protein A-5PW affinity chromatography column (TOSOH, Japan) was used to determine the mAb titer concentration in the supernatant. The mobile phase A was a 20 mmol/L phosphate buffer (NaH2PO4·H2O + Na2HPO4) at pH 7.0, and the mobile phase B was 20 mmol/L phosphate buffer at pH 2.5. The standard and samples were diluted with the mobile phase A before analysis. The chromatographic conditions were as follows: the sample chamber temperature at 10 °C, the column temperature at 25 °C, and the flow rate at 2 mL/min. The sample was separated by the pH gradient from 0% B to 100% B in 2 min. The eluted titer was detected at a wavelength of 280 nm and the titer concentration was calculated using the standard curve ranging from 0.2 to 4.0 mg/mL. The mAb purification The samples were purified by affinity chromatography on a 1-mL mAb Purix A65 gravity column (Sepax Technologies, China). The gravity column was washed first with purified water, disinfected with ≥5 mL of the 0.1 M NaOH solution, and rinsed with an affinity equilibrium solution (20 mM phosphate buffer and 150 mM NaCl at pH 7) until the droplets became neutral. The column was then further equilibrated with the affinity equilibration solution. The sample was loaded on the column and washed with the affinity equilibration solution. The mAb was eluted with ≥5 mL of the 25 mM sodium citrate-citric acid buffer at pH 3.5. The eluted mAb was collected, and the concentration was determined. The purified mAb was stored at −80 °C for the purity analyses. The purity analysis by size exclusion chromatography The purified mAb samples were analyzed using a Vanquish HPLC system (Thermo Fisher, USA) equipped with a TSKgel G3000SWxl molecular size exclusion column (TOSOH, Japan). The 50 mM phosphate and 300 mM NaCl buffer at pH 6.8 was used as a mobile phase. The flow rate was 0.8 mL/min, the injection volume was 10 µL, the column temperature was 25 °C, the acquisition wavelength was 280 nm, and the sample chamber temperature was 10 °C. The level of aggregation was expressed as the relative percentage of peak areas. The purity analysis by strong cation exchange chromatography The purified mAb samples were also analyzed with a Proteomix SCX-NP analytical column (5 µm, 4.6 × 150 mm, Sepax Technologies) equipped with a Vanquish HPLC system. The samples were first desalted by liquid exchange. The mAb sample (100 µg) was added to a 10 kD ultrafiltration tube, purified water (500 µL) added, vortexed, and centrifuged at 13,000 rpm for 10 min. The mAb concentration in the retentate was measured with a NanoDrop one spectrophotometer. After desalting, the samples were diluted to 5.0 mg/mL with purified water and then mixed by vortex before injection. The HPLC system consisted of four mobile phases: 125 mM sodium dihydrogen phosphate as mobile phase A, 125 mM disodium phosphate as mobile phase B, 1 M sodium chloride solution as mobile phase C, and ultra-pure water as mobile phase D. For the separation, the mobile phases A and B were maintained at constant rates of 9.3 and 40.7%, respectively at the entire duration. The mobile phase C was increased from 4 to 40% in 30 min. The flow rate was 0.5 mL/min. Protein peaks were measured by UV absorption at 280 nm. The glycosylation assay The GlycoWorks RapiFluor-MS N-glycan kit (Waters, USA) was used for sample preparation of the glycan analysis. First, the sample was diluted to 2 mg/mL with purified water. Then a 7.5 µL of the diluted sample was denatured, cooled, and incubated to release glycosyl groups, and RapiFluor-MS reagents were added to label the glycosyl groups. Finally, the sample was loaded on GlycoWorks HILIC µElution extraction plate for activation, cleaning, elution, and dilution before injection for HPLC analysis. The prepared glycan samples were analyzed by an ACQUITY UPLC system with a glycan BEH amide column (2.1 × 150 mm, 130 Å, 1.7 µm, Waters, USA), using a solution of 50 mM ammonium formate at pH 4.4 as mobile phase A and 100% acetonitrile as mobile phase B. The column temperature was kept at 60 °C, and the flow rate was stabilized at 0.4 mL/min, gradient elution was performed. The separated glycans were detected with a fluorescence detector with an excitation wavelength of 265 nm and the emission wavelength of 425 nm. After the glycosylation profile was obtained, the glycan species of the known glycosylation profile of the antibody protein were calibrated, and the glycosylation changes were analyzed according to the normalized peak areas. The mAb binding activity assay The relative binding activity of mAb was determined by an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). IgE (100 µL/well, Shanghai Maitai Junao Biotechnology Co., Ltd., China) was added to the microtiter plate (Corning, USA) for antigen coating, and incubated overnight in a refrigerator at 2–8 °C. The next day, PBST (1000 mL 10 mM PBS and 0.5 mL Tween 20) plus 3%BSA (Sigma, USA) was used as the blocking solution, PBST + 1%BSA as the diluent solution. The sample was diluted to 10 µg/mL, and then further diluted to 12 concentration points at a 3-fold dilution for each consequent point. Goat anti-human Kappa-HRP (Southern Biotech, USA) was used as the secondary antibody. A 3,3′,5,5′-tetramethylbenzidine chromogenic solution (50 µL/well, Kangwei Century, China) was added to develop color and finally, a 0.5 M H2SO4 solution (50 µL/well) was added to stop the color reaction. The SpectraMax iD5 multi-function microplate reader (Molecular Devices, USA) was used to read the absorbance at wavelengths of 450 and 570 nm, respectively. The curve was drawn using the four-parameter fitting regression model with the SoftMax Pro computer software. The half-maximal effect concentration (EC50) from the curve was obtained, and the relative activity was reported by calculating the EC50 ratio of the control to the experimental sample. Statistical analysis Results were analyzed by GraphPad Prism 9.0 software (GraphPad, United States). The data were expressed as means ± SD of three independent experiments performed in triplicate measurements. An ANOVA analysis was used to evaluate the differences among the treatments.

Conclusion In this study, the contents of carbohydrates and flavonoids in the three pine needle extracts were determined, and 38 compounds in the pine needle polysaccharide extract were identified. It has been demonstrated that the pine needle polysaccharide extract can be used to improve the viable cell density and viability of CHO cells and increase the mAb production. Furthermore, the pine needle polysaccharide extract was able to reduce the level of acidic charge variants and modulate the glycosylation profile. The utilization of natural plant extracts is a new research area to develop new raw materials for controlling the quality of biopharmaceutical products, especially biosimilars. Our pioneering exploration provides a new direction for future cell culture process optimization and the development of a culture medium system.

 Keywords Charge variants CHO cell culture glycosylation pine needle extracts The author(s) reported there is no funding associated with the work featured in this article. Introduction

With the successful uses of mAb therapeutics to treat human diseases, the identification of suitable supplements for the development of new CHO cell culture media to increase mAb yields have become extremely important.[ 1 ] From the traditional animal serum medium to the chemically defined (CD) medium used today, medium components and their concentrations for increasing the yield of different types of mAbs have been greatly improved. Since the CD medium does not need to add substances, such as fetal bovine serum (FBS), the variation between media batches decreases greatly. As a result, the repeatability of the CHO cell culture increases, and the process becomes more stable and robust.[ 2 ]

Many studies have found that pine needles are extremely rich in flavonoids, vitamins, amino acids, mineral elements, alkaloids, and polysaccharides.[ 11 ] And possess hypoglycemic, lipid regulation, antitumor, anti-aging, and antibacterial properties.[ 12 , 13 ] The natural water-soluble bioflavonoid concentrates and alkaloids from pine needle extracts have antioxidant activity functions, which can effectively remove free radicals.[ 14–16 ] Plant polysaccharides have a wide range of biological activities and desirable functional properties.[ 17 ] It has been reported that some small antioxidant molecules without direct nutritional value added to the cell culture medium can increase the productivity of CHO cells or protect the mAb from being oxidized.[ 18 ] Many infrequently used sugars, and the corresponding cellular response toward them as substrates led to differences in the protein N-glycosylation profile of a recombinant glycoprotein.[ 19 ] It has also been reported that the addition of bioflavonoids to animal cell cultures can effectively reduce the acidic charge variants on recombinant mAbs and their dual variable regions. Besides reducing the acidic charge variants of mAbs, the use of bioflavonoids can improve the structure and function of antibodies to varying degrees,[ 20 ] as well as product quality with less heterogeneity. The antioxidants, bioflavonoids, and polysaccharides in the pine needle extract have potential effects on the growth of CHO cells and the production of mAbs.

In this study, three types of Masson pine needle extracts, water extract (PNWE), ethanol extract (PNEE), and polysaccharide extract (PNPE), were used to evaluate their effects on CHO cell growth, cell metabolism, and titer, charge variant, glycosylation and biological activity of mAb in a fed-batch process. The contents of carbohydrates, flavonoids, and chemical compounds in the pine needle extracts were determined to identify the possible relationship with the components present in these extracts. To our knowledge, there is not a precedent report for the use of pine needle extracts as supplements for CHO cell culture media.

 Materials and methods Chemicals, reagents, and pine needle extracts

Dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) and dextrose dry powder were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (USA). Formic acid, methanol, acetonitrile, water, and trifluoroacetic acid (TFA) were ordered from Thermo Fisher Scientific (USA). Phenol concentrated sulfuric acid, sodium chloride, sodium hydroxide, phosphate-buffered saline (PBS), and aluminum chloride were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., China. Rutin standard was ordered from Chengdu Nakeli Bio-Technology Corp. China. Chemically defined medium CHO 050, and supplement CD Feed were provided by Jianshun Biotechnology Co., Ltd., China, and the cell line used was a stable recombinant CHO K1 cell line provided by Thousand Oaks Biopharmaceuticals Corp., China. PNWE and PNEE were purchased from Shaanxi Sinuote Biotechnology Co., Ltd., China. PNPE was obtained from Lanzhou Wotelaisi Biotechnology Corp., China. PNWE and PNEE were extracted from the pine needle by water and 75% ethanol, respectively. PNPE were obtained from the pine needle by multi-step extraction with water. In PNPE 50% of the active ingredients are the polysaccharides according to the specification.

 Determinations of carbohydrate and flavonoid contents

The carbohydrate content in the pine needle extracts was determined through the method of phenol-sulfuric acid using glucose as the standard. A stock solution with a glucose concentration of 0.1 mg/mL was prepared in water. A set of the standard solutions ranging from 0.02 to 1.0 mg/mL glucose were made for the standard curve. The sample (1 mg) was added to 10 mL of purified water and sonicated for 30 min. The supernatant was analyzed for the carbohydrate content. After adding 0.5 mL of 6% phenol and 2.5 mL of concentrated sulfuric acid solution to 1 mL of the standard and sample solutions, respectively, they were mixed and cooled at room temperature for 30 min, and absorbance at 490 nm was measured with an Evolution 260 Bio UV-Vis spectrophotometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA). The carbohydrate content in the sample was determined from the standard curve.

The flavonoid content in the pine needle extracts was determined by using an aluminum chloride colorimetric method. Rutin dissolved in 50% methanol was used as the flavonoid standard and the standard calibration curve was prepared in the concentrations ranging from 10 and 80 µg/mL. For the extraction of flavornoids, 200 mg of the sample was added in 20 mL of 50% methanol, and sonicated for 30 min. The sample extract (2 mL) was then mixed with 1 mL of 1% aluminum chloride and 7 mL of 50% methanol. The mixtures were allowed to stand for 30 min at the room temperature and the absorbance was measured at 277 nm spectrophotometrically. The flavonoid content in the sample was determined from the standard curve.

 Identification of chemical compounds

Each of the pine needle extracts (1 g) was accurately weighed into a 50 mL centrifugal tube and 20 mL of 75% methanol solution was added. Sonicated for 30 min, and the solution was filtrated. A 10.0-mL of the filtrate was dried under a reduced pressure. The dried sample was re-dissolved in 5 mL 75% methanol and then filtered with a 0.22 µm Polyether sulfone (PES) membrane. The filtrate was used for the identification of the chemical compounds.

Identification was performed using a Zeno TOF 7600 mass spectrometer (SCIEX, USA) equipped with a Sepax GP-C18 analytical column (1.8 µm 2.1 × 150 mm, Sepax Technologies, Inc., China) and an ACQUITY UPLC system (Waters, USA). Mobile phase A was 0.1% formic acid in water and Mobile phase B was 0.1% formic acid in acetonitrile. The mobile gradient was 5% B at the first 3 min, 5–75%B from 3 to 10 min, 75–100% B from 10 to 10.5 min, 100% B from 10.5 to 16.5 min, and 100–5% B from 16.5 to 20 min. The column temperature was 35 °C and the flow rate was 0. 3 mL/min. The ESI ion source was used for the analysis. The ESI ion source settings were as follows: ion source gases 1 and 2 at 60 psi, curtain gas at 35 psi, CAD gas at 9 psi, temperature at 600 °C. TOF start-stop mass between 30 and 1000 Da, declustering potential at −80 V, collision energy at −10 V. MS/MS conditions were as follows: TOF start-stop mass between 20 and 1000 Da, collision energy at −35 V, CE spread at 15 V, accumulation time at 0.15 s, and an injection volume at 3 µL. The compound identification was carried out through the Sciex database and the compound was confirmed with both TIC and MS/MS spectrum matching scores of >70%.

 Cell fed-batch culture

The stock solutions of the pine needle extracts were prepared in water at a concentration of 10 mg/mL. The stock solutions were sonicated for 30 min to allow the extracts to be dissolved completely and then filtered by 0.22 µm PES membrane before use. The cell line was serially propagated through separate seed train inoculums to generate enough cells for inoculation. Based on the preliminary experimental results, it was decided to use three concentrations of 5, 10, and 15 mg/L as the experimental concentration of the subsequent fed-batch culture for PNWE and PNEE. PNPE has a large concentration span, considering that the polysaccharide components have different effects on the charge variants and glycosylation of subsequent mAbs, three concentrations of 5, 50, and 100 mg/L were determined as the experimental concentrations of fed-batch culture. Nine experimental treatments with one control were used and each treatment including the control replicated three times. Independent cultures were performed in 50-mL cell culture TPP tubes (Switzerland). The working volume in each tube was 25 mL, and the seeding density was 1.0 × 106 viable cells/mL. The extracts were added to the cell culture media on Day 0 and the cells were harvested on Day 14. VCD and cell viability were determined with Vi-cell XR (Beckman Coulter, USA). Glucose, glutamine, lactate, ammonium, glutamate, pH, and osmolarity were determined with a BioProfile 400 (Nova BioMedical, USA). All samples were taken daily and assayed before feeding.

The cells were fed with the CD feed on the 3, 5, 7, 9, 11, and 13 days, respectively. The two types of CD feeds were added at 4 and 0.4% of the feeding-day culture volume, respectively. Glucose was always kept at a concentration between 2 and 3 g/L based on the results tested daily. When the VCD exceeded 1.0 × 106 viable cells/mL, the cell density of the sample was diluted in a 1:1 ratio with PBS before measurement. A temperature was shifted from 37 to 32 °C on the 7th day of the culture. After the 14th day, the samples were centrifuged with a high-speed refrigerated centrifuge (Beckman Coulter, USA) at 20 °C, 3900 g for 30 min, and the supernatants were collected, respectively.

 The mAb titer assay

An e2695 HPLC system (Waters, USA) with a TSKgel Protein A-5PW affinity chromatography column (TOSOH, Japan) was used to determine the mAb titer concentration in the supernatant. The mobile phase A was a 20 mmol/L phosphate buffer (NaH2PO4·H2O + Na2HPO4) at pH 7.0, and the mobile phase B was 20 mmol/L phosphate buffer at pH 2.5. The standard and samples were diluted with the mobile phase A before analysis. The chromatographic conditions were as follows: the sample chamber temperature at 10 °C, the column temperature at 25 °C, and the flow rate at 2 mL/min. The sample was separated by the pH gradient from 0% B to 100% B in 2 min. The eluted titer was detected at a wavelength of 280 nm and the titer concentration was calculated using the standard curve ranging from 0.2 to 4.0 mg/mL.

 The mAb purification

The samples were purified by affinity chromatography on a 1-mL mAb Purix A65 gravity column (Sepax Technologies, China). The gravity column was washed first with purified water, disinfected with ≥5 mL of the 0.1 M NaOH solution, and rinsed with an affinity equilibrium solution (20 mM phosphate buffer and 150 mM NaCl at pH 7) until the droplets became neutral. The column was then further equilibrated with the affinity equilibration solution. The sample was loaded on the column and washed with the affinity equilibration solution. The mAb was eluted with ≥5 mL of the 25 mM sodium citrate-citric acid buffer at pH 3.5. The eluted mAb was collected, and the concentration was determined. The purified mAb was stored at −80 °C for the purity analyses.

 The purity analysis by size exclusion chromatography

The purified mAb samples were analyzed using a Vanquish HPLC system (Thermo Fisher, USA) equipped with a TSKgel G3000SWxl molecular size exclusion column (TOSOH, Japan). The 50 mM phosphate and 300 mM NaCl buffer at pH 6.8 was used as a mobile phase. The flow rate was 0.8 mL/min, the injection volume was 10 µL, the column temperature was 25 °C, the acquisition wavelength was 280 nm, and the sample chamber temperature was 10 °C. The level of aggregation was expressed as the relative percentage of peak areas.

 The purity analysis by strong cation exchange chromatography

The purified mAb samples were also analyzed with a Proteomix SCX-NP analytical column (5 µm, 4.6 × 150 mm, Sepax Technologies) equipped with a Vanquish HPLC system. The samples were first desalted by liquid exchange. The mAb sample (100 µg) was added to a 10 kD ultrafiltration tube, purified water (500 µL) added, vortexed, and centrifuged at 13,000 rpm for 10 min. The mAb concentration in the retentate was measured with a NanoDrop one spectrophotometer. After desalting, the samples were diluted to 5.0 mg/mL with purified water and then mixed by vortex before injection. The HPLC system consisted of four mobile phases: 125 mM sodium dihydrogen phosphate as mobile phase A, 125 mM disodium phosphate as mobile phase B, 1 M sodium chloride solution as mobile phase C, and ultra-pure water as mobile phase D. For the separation, the mobile phases A and B were maintained at constant rates of 9.3 and 40.7%, respectively at the entire duration. The mobile phase C was increased from 4 to 40% in 30 min. The flow rate was 0.5 mL/min. Protein peaks were measured by UV absorption at 280 nm.

 The glycosylation assay

The GlycoWorks RapiFluor-MS N-glycan kit (Waters, USA) was used for sample preparation of the glycan analysis. First, the sample was diluted to 2 mg/mL with purified water. Then a 7.5 µL of the diluted sample was denatured, cooled, and incubated to release glycosyl groups, and RapiFluor-MS reagents were added to label the glycosyl groups. Finally, the sample was loaded on GlycoWorks HILIC µElution extraction plate for activation, cleaning, elution, and dilution before injection for HPLC analysis.

The prepared glycan samples were analyzed by an ACQUITY UPLC system with a glycan BEH amide column (2.1 × 150 mm, 130 Å, 1.7 µm, Waters, USA), using a solution of 50 mM ammonium formate at pH 4.4 as mobile phase A and 100% acetonitrile as mobile phase B. The column temperature was kept at 60 °C, and the flow rate was stabilized at 0.4 mL/min, gradient elution was performed. The separated glycans were detected with a fluorescence detector with an excitation wavelength of 265 nm and the emission wavelength of 425 nm. After the glycosylation profile was obtained, the glycan species of the known glycosylation profile of the antibody protein were calibrated, and the glycosylation changes were analyzed according to the normalized peak areas.

 The mAb binding activity assay

The relative binding activity of mAb was determined by an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). IgE (100 µL/well, Shanghai Maitai Junao Biotechnology Co., Ltd., China) was added to the microtiter plate (Corning, USA) for antigen coating, and incubated overnight in a refrigerator at 2–8 °C. The next day, PBST (1000 mL 10 mM PBS and 0.5 mL Tween 20) plus 3%BSA (Sigma, USA) was used as the blocking solution, PBST + 1%BSA as the diluent solution.

The sample was diluted to 10 µg/mL, and then further diluted to 12 concentration points at a 3-fold dilution for each consequent point. Goat anti-human Kappa-HRP (Southern Biotech, USA) was used as the secondary antibody. A 3,3′,5,5′-tetramethylbenzidine chromogenic solution (50 µL/well, Kangwei Century, China) was added to develop color and finally, a 0.5 M H2SO4 solution (50 µL/well) was added to stop the color reaction. The SpectraMax iD5 multi-function microplate reader (Molecular Devices, USA) was used to read the absorbance at wavelengths of 450 and 570 nm, respectively. The curve was drawn using the four-parameter fitting regression model with the SoftMax Pro computer software. The half-maximal effect concentration (EC50) from the curve was obtained, and the relative activity was reported by calculating the EC50 ratio of the control to the experimental sample.

 Statistical analysis

Results were analyzed by GraphPad Prism 9.0 software (GraphPad, United States). The data were expressed as means ± SD of three independent experiments performed in triplicate measurements. An ANOVA analysis was used to evaluate the differences among the treatments.

 Results Carbohydrate and flavonoid contents

The carbohydrate and flavonoid contents in the three pine needle extracts are shown in Table 1. PNWE had 4.74% more carbohydrate content than PNEE, and PNPE had the highest carbohydrate content (96.03%). There was no difference in flavonoid content between PNWE and PNEE, and the flavonoid content in PNPE was ∼1% lower than that in PNWE and PNEE (Table 1).

 Chemical compounds identified in PNPE

The chromatograms of the three pine needle extracts are shown in Figure 1. Mass spectrometry data were interpreted by analyzing their accurate mass information and MS/MS spectrum in a negative ion mode. When both accurate mass and MS/MS spectrum of a compound matched to the information in the database by >70% matching score and this compound was considered to be confirmed. With the use of those criteria, 38 compounds were identified from PNPE (Table 2). Some of the bioflavonoids identified may be the compounds that influence the charge variants of mAb.[ 20 ] No compounds were identified from PNWE and PNEE by searching the database (results not shown). An additional verification study is needed for the compound identification in PNWE and PNEE.

Compared with the control, the viable cell density decreased significantly at 10 and 15 mg/L PNWE concentrations (Figure 2a), indicating the inhibition of the CHO cell growth. The VCD at the 5 mg/L PNWE was similar to that of the control, but it was significantly higher in the last three days, indicating that PNWE at this concentration might have a delaying effect on the death of CHO cells. At the last four days of the cell culture, the cell viability of the three PNWE concentrations was higher than that of the control (Figure 2d). The inhibitory effect observed in the PNWE extract may be associated with the higher percentage of the non-polysaccharide compounds (Table 1). The effects of the PNEE extract on the VCD and cell viability were very similar to those of the PNWE extract (Figures 2b,e). The PNPE treatments had little effect on VCD and cell viability during the first 11 days (Figures 2c,f). However, the highest VCD reached 16.4 × 106 cells/mL at 5 mg/L concentration, and the highest VCD at all the PNPE concentrations exceeded that of the control group. On the 14th day, the PNPE treatments maintained a high VCD of about 12.0 × 106 cells/mL and viability of about 82.0%, compared to the VCD of 10.2 × 106 cells/mL, and the viability of 78.3% in the control. Apparently, the high polysaccharide levels may help maintain the higher VCD and cell viability (Figures 2c,f).

Effects of the pine needle extracts on the growth and cell viability of CHO cells under Fed-batch culture conditions. The VCD (a) and cell viability (d) in 0 (control), 5, 10, and 15 mg/L PNWE; The VCD (b) and cell viability (e) in 0 (control), 5, 10, and 15 mg/L PNEE; The VCD (c) and cell viability (f) in 0 (control), 5, 50, and 100 mg/L PNPE.

The glucose consumption during the culture period was reduced when the 10 and 15 mg/L of PNWE and PNEE, respectively, were used, but it was similar in the other treatments (data not shown). The addition of three extracts did not impact the contents of glutamine, lactic acid, ammonium, and glutamic acid.

 Effects on the mAb titers

The mAb titer increased significantly (p < 0.01) at the 5 mg/L PNWE, but tended to decrease with increased PNWE concentrations (Figure 3). A similar trend was also observed for the PNEE treatments. However, the effect of PNPE on the mAb titer was different from those of PNWE and PNEE. The mAb titer increased from 2.3 to 2.8 g/L with the PNPE concentrations increasing from 5 to 100 mg/L, showing a dose-dependent relationship. The p-values for the results of three PNPE concentrations were <0.001 compared to the control. The results indicate that the high levels of the non-polysaccharide compounds may have a negative impact, while the polysaccharides may have an enhanced effect on the mAb titers.

The mAb titers produced by the CHO cells grown in the pine needle extracts in a fed-batch process. *, **, and *** indicate the significance at p < 0.05, p < 0.01, and p < 0.001, respectively, compared to the control.

 Effects on the mAb purity

Besides the impact of genetic sequence, the mAb purity can be affected significantly by the upstream Fed-batch culture process and the downstream mAb purification process.[ 21 ] The addition of a pine needle changed the media composition that may impact the CHO cell growth and then the mAb purity. The purities of the main peaks (MP) by SEC were >99% for all the treatments including the control (Table 3). There were no statistically significant differences in the SEC purity among all the treatments, indicating the pine needle did not impact the molecular size of the mAb.

In CEX, the acidic peak levels decreased by 3.4–4.5% in the PNWE treatments and 3.4–4.8% in the PNEE treatments, while the basic peak levels increased by 2.0–6.0% in the PNWE treatments and 1.0–6.0% in the PNEE treatments (Figure 4). Many of these changes were statistically significant at the 0.01 and 0.001 significance levels. But these changes became more profound with the increased PNWE and PNEE concentrations from 5 to 15 mg/L. The additions of the PNWE and PNEE had minor influences on the main peak levels. The acidic peak levels in the PNPE treatments were all reduced significantly, and the largest decrease was at the concentration of 50 mg/L, reaching 3.9% (p < 0.001) (Figure 4). The basic peak levels increased with an increased PNPE concentration. The levels of the main species slightly decreased at the 100 mg/L concentration and increased slightly at 5 and 50 mg/L concentrations.

The differences between control and treatments in the levels of the acidic peak, main peak, and basic peak of the mAb produced by the CHO cells grown in the pine needle extracts compared with the control. *, **, and *** indicate the significance at p < 0.05, p < 0.01, and p < 0.001, respectively compared to the control.

Apparently, the pine needle extracts were able to reduce the acidic charge variants of the mAbs, but did not significantly change the main species. This property is very important for regulating acidic and basic charge variants of a therapeutic protein, which allows us to achieve specific target levels during the production. Many studies have been reported that the presence of acidic charge variants may have a certain degree of influence on the effectiveness and function of the proteins.[ 21–23 ]

Effects on the mAb glycosylation

Protein glycosylation is an important post-translational modification event, and has a non-negligible impact on protein structure and function,[ 24 , 25 ] represents one of the most important critical quality attributes (CQAs). During the upstream production, glycosylation is altered by cell line, process conditions, and media and supplement formulations.[ 26 ] A total of ten glycoforms were found in the proteins produced in the experiments, of which G0F accounted for the highest percentage, reaching about 70% (Table 4). PNWE and PNEE did not show any effect on glycoforms except G0, where G0 levels increased with the increased concentrations of both extracts. PNPE showed different effects on glycoforms. PNPE decreased the G0F level by 8.7% at the 100 mg/L concentration compared to the control. Decreases in G0 minus GlcNAc and G0F minus GlcNAc were also observed. However, the two glycoforms G1Fa and G1Fb increased with the increased PNPE concentrations, where G1Fa increased by 0.56, 4.41, and 6.7% at the three increased concentrations, respectively, and G1Fb increased by 0.96, 2.07, and 2.91%, respectively. G0 and G1F GlcNAc reached the highest level at the 50 mg/L concentration, and G0 glycoform decreased at the 100 mg/L concentration. While Man5 and Man6 reached the highest level at the 5 mg/L PNPE concentration. PNPE had more effect on glycosylation than the other two extracts. Therefore, PNPE could be an effective component used to control product quality associated with glycosylation.

The binding activity of mAb has strong clinical relevance. The results of relative potency and EC50 are shown in Figure 5. Compared to the control, the same trend was observed, the binding activity was lower at two low extract concentrations and higher at the high extract concentration. However, according to the mAb requirement for CHO K1 cells cultured in this study, most of the results were within an acceptable range of 70–130%. Hence, the addition of the pine needle extract had no significant effect on the mAb binding activity.

The effects of the pine needle extracts on the relative binding activity and EC50 of mAb produced by the CHO cells grown in the three extracts. No significant difference was observed.

 Discussion

The differences in carbohydrate and flavonoid contents between PNWE and PNEE were relatively small, indicating the water and ethanol extraction had a limited effect on the components of the pine needles (Table 1). PNPE with a much higher carbohydrate content was different from the other two extracts and appeared to be a better choice for cell culture.

In the present fed-batch condition, the pine needle extracts increased the mAb yield. Therefore, it can be determined that the pine needle extracts may be suitable to increase the viable cell density and cell viability and then increase the production of the target protein. Among them, the results obtained by adding PNPE were by far the best. When the PNPE concentration reached 100 mg/L, the VCD and cell viability on the 14th day were still at a high level, and the target protein production reached the highest level (Figure 3), indicating that this may not be an optimal PNPE concentration. However, the PNWE and PNEE had obvious inhibitory effects on the growth of CHO cells at the concentration of 15 mg/L. Clearly it was not such a case for PNPE. The pine needle sugar components may have a positive effect on the cell growth and production. The results of this research can also be used in process scale-up to increase the mAb production.

For charge variants, the complete elimination of both acidic and basic charge variants is impractical and unnecessary. Therefore, it is necessary to evaluate the differences in stability and function of acidic, basic, and main species and compare them with the final target to ensure the efficacy and safety of mAbs. Various flavonoids have been reported to significantly reduce the overall levels of acidic charge variants on recombinant proteins at specific concentrations.[ 20 ] At the same time, there is a nominal drop in recombinant protein production. The pine needle extracts used in this study reduced the overall levels of acidic charge variants on the mAb proteins with increased tilters in 5 and 10 mg/L PNWE and PNEE, and three concentrations of PNPE (Figures 3 and 4). Flavonoids in all three extracts were detected by the aluminum chloride colorimetric method and identified by the mass spectrometry (Table 2). The reductions in the charge variants were related to relatively high flavonoid levels (Figure 4 and Table 1). These results explained the reason for the reduction of acidic charge variants, which is similar to previous reports.

Glycosylation characteristics can be affected by various conditions including cell lines, culture media composition, supplements,[ 27–30 ] and culture processes.[ 31 ] An effective approach to control the glycosylation profile is to alter CHO cell culture media components to target specific oligosaccharide structures. The sugars in the media can meet the energy requirements of CHO cells and they are also the carbohydrate sources that enable the glycosylation pathway to proceed. Most of them rely on glucose for energy sources, but recent studies found that many uncommon sugars other than glucose also have a non-negligible effect on the glycosylation profile of recombinant proteins.[ 19 ] This study illustrated that multiple types of sugars in PNPE changed the mAb glycosylation profile. Moreover, different types of mAbs produced by CHO cells have different requirements for glycosylation, and the appropriate glycosylation characteristics have to be achieved according to the desired mechanism of molecular action and desired proportion of antibody glycoforms.[ 32–34 ] In the field of biosimilars, the glycosylation characteristics of the mAb produced need to match the original drug, so it is necessary to adjust the glycosylation characteristics of the generic drug. The PNPE can effectively modify the glycoforms (Table 4), and therefore it can be used as a supplement to regulate the mAb glycosylation, such as changing the levels of G0F, G1F, G2F, etc.

The use of the extracts is simple and cheap. The cost of each extract in each liter of the culture media is <1 cent, which is significantly lower than that of peptones. However, additional studies are needed to identify specific compound(s) responsible for the changes in mAb productivity and quality due to the addition of the pine needle extracts. Because of diversity in pine needle sources, the production of consistent manufacturing batches will be a major concern. Therefore, additional quality control for the manufacturing is needed when these extracts are used in the mAb production.

 Conclusion

In this study, the contents of carbohydrates and flavonoids in the three pine needle extracts were determined, and 38 compounds in the pine needle polysaccharide extract were identified. It has been demonstrated that the pine needle polysaccharide extract can be used to improve the viable cell density and viability of CHO cells and increase the mAb production. Furthermore, the pine needle polysaccharide extract was able to reduce the level of acidic charge variants and modulate the glycosylation profile. The utilization of natural plant extracts is a new research area to develop new raw materials for controlling the quality of biopharmaceutical products, especially biosimilars. Our pioneering exploration provides a new direction for future cell culture process optimization and the development of a culture medium system.
